case_vignette: A 65-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for stiffness in his arm. He states that he has been having trouble combing his hair and reaching objects that are high on the shelf. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, obesity, and hypertension. His current medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient admits to leading a sedentary life in which he tends to stay home and watch television. He does not engage in any physical or strenuous activity. On physical exam the patient has decreased passive and active range of motion of his shoulder. Strength of the patient's upper extremity is 4/5.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing stiffness in my arm, and I'm having trouble combing my hair and reaching for things high on the shelf.
Is this stiffness accompanied by joint pain or swelling?
No, I didn't mention any pain or swelling, just stiffness.
Is the stiffness limited to your arm or affecting other joints as well?
It's just in my arm.
Have you noticed any recent injuries or trauma to your arm?
No, I haven't had any injuries or trauma.

Do you have a family history of rheumatic conditions?

**Final Diagnosis:** Rheumatoid Arthritis (if there's a positive family history), otherwise, most likely Primary Cervical Spondylosis (if there's no family history and symptoms are localized to the arm).
